indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number and type of infrastructure projects implemented; number of training events conducted and number of people trained across the various sectors by the project; food crop productivity and diversification; farm and off-farm income level; mobile phone connectivity across the district.

baseline.comment: At the time of the start of project implementation in 2008, there was only 3 primary health clinics in the entire district; no health center; large section of the district has no primary health facilities; 31 primary school buildings with at least 50% using makeshift structures; no high school; only about 10% of all instructional staff members hold teacher training certificates and on government payroll; no science laboratories on any school; no concrete bridges in any part of the district; no lighting in the clinics; only about 20% of all hand pumps constructed were functioning; few community water and sanitation management committees but not functioning; food crop production - rice, cassava, fruits and vegetables - are extremely low to the point that most of the food requirements are met through import from other districts and counties; and wealth community participation and local governance .

result.title: Objective
result.description: To increase resilience of poor, agricultural-dependent communities and decrease vulnerability of agricultural sector to climate change in Liberia.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % change in projected food production in target areas given existing and projected climate change (AMAT indicator 1.2.8)

baseline.comment:
Upland: Not currently measured
Lowland:% tons/year of low-land rice - site specific information
Baselines to be established during inception

target.comment:
Upland & lowland: Formal tracking system established to cover diversified food commodities
Lowland: 10% average annual increase of rice production due to cultivation of traditional rice varieties as â€˜adaptation optionâ€™
Application beyond demonstration sites due to policy up-scaling actions

actual.comment:
In 2012 a climate change vulnerability and livelihood assessment was conducted in the two pilot counties, specifically in two districts, Panta and Gbarzon. Eight (8) demonstration sites were established eight Farmer Field Schools (FFS) formed with 25 farmers in each of the FFS. Several potential adaptation measures were identified for testing at these sites so as to enhance resilience.
In addition to the vulnerability assessment, a capacity assessment of the agriculture sector was conducted in the agriculture sector to identify key climate change management needs and inform the development of a capacity development plan to manage climate change in the sector. A Climate Change Management (CCM) Capacity Development Plan was developed for the sector with a three-prong approach: a) training and research capacity for sector technicians/field staff and university students, b) institutional strengthening of the MOA and other sector agencies (including agriculture/forestry colleges) and c) review of policies, laws and investment framework governing agriculture sector development as well as advocacy for mainstreaming climate changes into these policies/investments. Additionally, a Climate Risk Management (CRM) Strategy was developed informed by both the findings of the vulnerability assessment and the capacity assessment. Implementation of the CCMCD Plan started in September of 2013.
Since the roll-out of implementation the CCMCD plan and CRM as well as the testing of innovations at the there have been significant progress toward achievement of the project key objectives. These include the following:
More than 200 farmers (both pilot areas and non pilot towns) are now aware and can relate specific climate change hazards to impacts on their farms; farmers are also aware of coping measures both through the demonstration sites learning and, for farmers not part of the FFS, from the exchanges with FFS farmers and extension support of the MOA field staff.
Framers in Panta and Gbarzon are now rightly timing key activities in the rice farming cycle including clearing/preparation of farmland, planting, etc. This is as opposed to having to replant the rice later in the year when the previously planted seeds did not germinate because of late rains. Replanting rice later in the year when germination failed was widely reported during the vulnerability assessment as a coping measure by farmers in both Panta and Gbarzon Districts of Bong and Grand Counties.
Framers
Additionally, about 90% of the 200 FFS farmers are now into lowland farming at their own farms as compared to about 55% when the FFS started. This is a direct gain for the Ministry of Agriculture’s policy for more and more farmers to move into lowland farming.
A strikingly impressive progress to note here is that the Ministry of Agriculture reported an increase in rice and cassava production activities between 2013 and 2014 as indicated by its record of increase in number of active framers in Bong County (those with actual rice farms during the period- and whose farms were visited and production authenticated). According to the MOA’s Annual Reports of 2013 and 2014, actual rice farmers in Bong County (one of the pilot counties) increased from 1,413 farmers in 2013 to 5,729 (about 305%). Women farmers constituted the larger share of this. For example, in 2013, the number of women farmers with actual farms in Bong County was 756 compared to 657 men. For cassava, Bong County recorded figure of 2,712 in 2014 rising from 1033 in 2013.
The MOA also reported increase in rice production activities in the other pilot county of Grand Gedeh. However, the increase was not as large as that of Bong. Actual rice farmers in Grand Gedeh County increased from 958 (501 males 457 females) in 2013 to 1,185 in 2014, representing 23.7% increase.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened institutional and individual capacity to plan and manage climate change in the agriculture sector in Liberia.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No. of staff trained on technical adaptation themes(AMAT indicator 2.2.1.1)

baseline.comment:
Technical staff: 0
County level staff: 0
University students: 0
Type and level:
No budget allocations

target.comment:
Technical staff: 60 (30 Men and 30 Women)
County level staff: 30 (10 in each county) (10 women and 10 men)
University students: 100 (50 women and 50 men)
(to be disaggregated by theme and by gender)
Type and level:
Budget allocations included in:
PRSII
Agriculture policy (LASIP)
Low-land rice production support programs

actual.comment:
Based on the capacity assessment of the sector mentioned above, a Climate Change Management (CCM) Capacity Development Plan was developed for the agriculture sector and implementation has been ongoing as follows: 1. Forty (40) technical staff (15 women and 25 men)- (20 MOA, 5 EPA, 5 MOT, 5 MIA and 5 FDA) trained on the concepts (nature, causes, issues, and impacts) of CC and current interventions (international and national) for adaptation/mitigation including existing coping measures;
2. fourteen (14) county level staffs integrated into project implementation teams in pilot counties to facilitate hands-on learning and enhance capacity to advice on CCA. These include 2 County Agriculture Coordinators (CACs), 6 Districts Agriculture Officers-DAOs, 2 County project Planners-CPPs, 2 County Development Officers-CDOs, 1 Field Officer of CARE and 1 Field Staff of Agency for Economic Development & Empowerment)
3. The two (2) leading universities (University of Liberia and Cuttington University) supported to revise the curricula of their colleges of agriculture, forestry and sustainable development (modules developed and validated for two (2) short courses on CCA to be administered every semester at the two universities) and to undertake one climate change research (40 students -20 male and 20 females, and 8 lecturers-all male , were involved in the training and research from data collection to analysis); Climate change topic are now being taught in already existing courses in the department of Agriculture and Forestry, University of Liberia and in the Department of Agriculture and Sustainable Development, Cuttington. The research was finalized and the report shared. The research/study was done on the “Biological and Scio-Economic Impacts of Climate Change on the Farming of Selected Crops in Panta and Gbarzon Districts in Liberia”.
42 students (equally disaggregated by gender) and 14 instructors (all male) for departments of agriculture, forestry and environmental science of seven universities in Liberia were trained hands-on to conduct climate change risk/vulnerability assessments in the agriculture sector at the Central Agriculture Research Institution (CARI) from on the 29th, 30th April and 1st May 2015 facilitated by a national training consultant. This training does not only increase knowledge of climate change, but will also support the process of the National Adaptation Planning Process and the national survey on the economics of adaptation.
Additionally, a Climate Change Resource Center is now being set up in Bong and grand Gedeh Counties. The centers will be a part of the platform for climate change learning information sharing by university and secondary school students as well as professional individuals and organizations working in the sector in these counties. It will provide different kinds of information on climate change and how to manage the risks associated, not only for agriculture sector, but for other development sectors. It will contain computers, books, reports of ongoing projects, links/websites to international resources as well as other reading materials. There will be conference facilities for holding symposiums and topic discussions with different interest groups. Activity at the center will focus on research and community outreach. The center will provide:
Research facilities, both online (web-based) and hard library of books/reading materials (reports, etc)
Briefing services, video shows (for raising awareness),
Public lectures, topical and other discussions with communities on climate change related issues
Seminars for schools, local government/policy makers and private sector people.
The main objective of the Resource Center is to enhance capacity of county/district levels stakeholders support management of risks associated with climate change through dissemination of up-dated and reliable information tailored to local needs

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Innovative, sustainable, socially appropriate adaptive measures piloted at the community level.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of targeted households that have adopted resilient livelihoods under existing and projected climate change (AMAT indicator 1.3.1.1)

baseline.comment:
Type and level: 0
(aside already exiting local coping mechanism)
No. of targeted households to be confirmed for each of the three demonstration site during inception of local level activities.0% of targeted households is the baseline.

target.comment:
Type and level: at least 4 different innovations at each demonstration site
(including the formal identification of locally existing coping strategies which are furthered and formalized as local adaptation measures)
80% of targeted households have adopted resilient livelihoods at demonstration sites.

actual.comment:
A climate change vulnerability assessment (a livelihood needs assessment of the impacts of climate change on farming) was conducted in the two pilot counties, specifically in two districts, Panta and Gbarzon of Bong and Grand Gedeh Counties respectively. Eight (8) towns were covered in the two districts, namely: Foequelleh, Bellemue, Garmu and Gbarnga-siaquelleh (Panta District, Bong County) and Tian Town, Zleh Town, Gaye Town and Puoh Town (Gbarzon District, Grand Gedeh County). The UNFAO led the vulnerability assessment. I took place from December 9 to 16, 2012. Before finalizing the report, the findings were validated in March 2013 in an extensively participatory process involving more than 200 farmers, partner institutions including AEDE, CARE, UNDP, etc. The assessment documented climate change hazards and their impacts on farming as well as the coping measures farmers were applying at the time. The study also documented vulnerabilities and alternative livelihood options farmers had in Panta and Gbarzon. Adaptive measures were identified together with farmers (including onse already being practiced by farmers, but with slight improvements for efficiency). Eight (8) demonstration sites were established in the eight towns covered and eight Farmer Field Schools (FFS) formed with 25 farmers in each of the FFS in each of the eight towns. Eight FFS Facilitators were identified and trained (facilitated by FAO) to lead learning activities at the FFS. Testing of innovations at the sites commence in May of 2013.
Innovation Testing: So far, three innovations have been tested successfully at each of the eight sites. The testing of innovations is being complimented by other essential trainings and awareness/sensitization activities. These can be summarized as follows:
Innovation Tested:
Improve reliability of water supply in the swamp through establishment of water harvesting systems (valley dams, valley tank/reservoirs) with appropriate water control measures;
CC Impact Being alleviate:
Crop failure and low productivity due to water stress
Results:
Successful in both Bong and Grand Gedeh
Innovation Tested:
Reduce floods by developing water control and drainage systems
CC Impact Being alleviate:
Crop failure due to flooding
Results:
Successful in both Bong and Grand Gedeh (Farmers well versed in this)
Innovation Tested:
Integrated soil fertility management through practices such as: green manure legumes, N-fixing agro-forestry trees, composting and animal manure application
CC Impact Being alleviate:
Low crop productivity resulting from soil erosion and reduced fertility due to land degradation
Results:
Successful in Bong and Grand Gedeh. However, the issue raised was the inappropriateness of the site used to test this innovation Grand Gedeh (no soil degradation issue was visible at the site in one of the tows: Tian Town FFS
Innovation Tested
Promote crop varieties resistant to pests and diseases
CC Impact Being alleviate:
Low productivity due to increased pest and diseases
Results:
IPM training: Agro-ecosystem analysis (AESA) being utilized by farmers
Additionally, four non-pilot towns have been reached by FAO and MOA extension officers with sensitizations of Climate change as well as lessons from the learning at demonstration sites.
The MOA has planned an assessment of the pilot districts (including both towns with demonstration sites and non-pilot towns) to authenticate/verify the following:
o The kinds and number of innovations tested and the extent of learning at the FFS
o The actual number of FFS farmers adopting the innovations at their individual farms, and
o The number of farmers in pilot towns which are adopting the measures on their farms as result of the outreach the project’s county team

baseline.comment:
All UNDP programmes and projects are Direct Implementation (DIM)
10 MACs using harmonized financial reporting tool – Funding Authorization and Certificate of Expenditure (FACE)
No capacity development plan
Draft National Implementation Operational Guide developed

target.comment:
1. Procurement certification of IPs and RPs procurement staff 2. Micro Assessments 3. 10 Finance staff - Certificate in Accounting Technicians Scheme, West Africa (ATSWA) 4. 2 workshops - Mid term programme review and annual programme review 5. 50 copies - NIM Toolkit 6. 4 quarterly programme board meeting
Communication 1.1. Produce at least 3 communication materials including News Board, “At a Glance” and “Country Office Update” 1.2. Produce at least 2 YouTube multimedia videos on UNDP projects to increase visibility 1.3. Organize at least one (1) knowledge/experience sharing workshop for media practitioners in the area of Development Communication 1.4. Produce at least 3 advocacy materials aimed at enhancing UNDP tagline and brand image. 1.5. Develop one Monitoring and Evaluation system to facilitate coordination of IP quarterly reporting. 1.6. Develop and implement a Resource Mobilization strategy for the UNDP Liberia CO. 1.7. Organize one (1) knowledge/experience sharing training on Resource Mobilization and Partnerships building. 1.8. Develop and implement a communications strategy to ensure effective communication of UNDP- GoL project results.

actual.comment: 30 staff from the IPs and RPs procurement were earmarked for Procurement certification but could not take place due to EVD outbreak. 14 national partners Micro Assessment was completed and the results will be used to determine the capacity building to address the gaps and determine the IP cash transfer modality. The Certification programme in Accounting Technicians Scheme, West Africa (ATSWA) and CPA was commissioned on 17th June 2014 for 36 Finance staff from IPs and RPs but was discontinued due to EVD. 100 copies of the NIM Toolkit which comprises of the National Implementation Operation Guide, Quick Guide Checklist and CDs were produced which will enable easy access to NIM business processes, tools and templates. Due to the EVD, 2 quarterly programme board meeting were conducted 3 communication materials including News Board, “At a Glance” and “Country Office Update” 2 YouTube multimedia videos on UNDP projects to increase visibility were produce one (1) knowledge/experience sharing workshop for media practitioners in the area of Development Communication Produce 3 advocacy materials aimed at enhancing UNDP tagline and brand image. Developed an Monitoring and Evaluation system to facilitate coordination of IP quarterly reporting and demonstration was done for the UNDP programme staff, IP and RPs. Developed a Resource Mobilization strategy for the UNDP Liberia CO.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen Liberia’s climate-related monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard.
2. Domestic finance committed to Meteorology Department, Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

baseline.comment:
1. Average capacity scorecard rating of 57 across men and women (see Annex 5).
2. Annual budget of US$ 64,480 allocated to Meteorology Department; annual budget of US$ 276,877 allocated to Hydrological Services; and annual budget of US$50,000 allocated to NDRC.

target.comment:
1. Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 134 for both men and women (see Annex 5).
2. 20% increase in annual domestic finance allocated to Meteorology Department, Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

actual.comment: Under the reporting period, there has been no increase in domestic finance to monitor and warn against climate hazards. However, we are optimistic that the awareness being generated about the importance of early warnings for the operations of different sectors and when alerts and warnings begin to be issued from the EWS Project and National Meteorological and Hydrological Services (NMHS), all this will prove the need for public finance and financing from private sources, such as the sales of weather products. The first year of implementation has been mired by the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease which slowed down several aspects of implementation, especially field-based activities and those involving collaboration with partners and external consultants.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Increased capacity of hydro-meteorological services and associated networks to monitor and predict extreme weather, climate-related hazards and climate trends.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network (fully operational).
2. Frequency of data transmission.
3. Number of sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced using improved information.

baseline.comment:
1. AWS: 0%
Hydrometric stations: 0%.
2. At present, the 1 AWS transmits data at the synoptic hours of (GMT) 06h00, 09h00, 12h00, 15h00, 18h00 and 00h00, although not consistently.
3. At present, the only sector-specific information produced is for the aviation sector.

target.comment:
1. AWS: 100% (at least 9 AWSs).
Hyrdometric: 100% (at least 6 stations).
2. 18 AWSs and hydrometric stations (11 new AWSs, 1 rehabilitated AWS, 6 hydrometric stations), transmitting continuously.
3. Sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced for three of the following: agriculture, water, aviation, fisheries/coastal water users, health, tourism, construction, energy and road, rail and sea transport.

actual.comment: Core activities around this output could not be implemented due to the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) and the subsequent delays in the procurement of equipment and services. The Government of Liberia requested UNDP to procure equipment along with services like training, installation and maintenance. Because of the low level of human capital, we feel that the procurement of equipment alone cannot guarantee EWS for Liberia and its long term sustainability. The long term agreement (LTA) to be issued by CIRDA is the best option for the country. The EVD also hampered other capacity building activities as experts could not come into the country and staff could not be accepted in several countries for training. In 2014, negotiations with the World Meteorological Organization Training Institutions in Nigeria and Kenya collapsed because of the EVD, but responses from both countries are advanced and students will be sent over by 4th quarter. Probably the most substantive deliverable for the year, besides training, will be the renovation of the building to be used as the National Meteorological Center (NMC) within the premises of the Roberts International Airport. This project is to begin during the 4th quarter.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Efficient and effective use of tailored climate, environmental and socio-economic data to produce appropriate information which can be communicated to government entities and communities to enable informed decision-making.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Number of communication channels operational to disseminate climate-related early warnings.
2. Percentage of population within the two targeted districts that has access to improved climate-related flood, storm and coastal surge warnings (disaggregated by gender).

baseline.comment:
1. At present, information is relayed to communities mostly via word-of-mouth, but without the structure of SOPs.
2. 0% of men
0 % of women.

target.comment:
1. At least 3 of the following: radio, television, print media (newspapers, flyers), word-of-mouth and mobile phone communication channels are operational.
2. 100 % of men
100 % of women.

actual.comment: These activities were delayed until equipment is procured, deployed and climate information is generated to be communicated to target users. There is no product to communicate at this stage.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Increased awareness in government, private sector and local communities of the major risks associated with climate change, and use of available information when formulating development policies and strategies.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Development frameworks that integrate climate information in their formulation.

baseline.comment: 1. The Agenda for Transformation (2012-2017) highlights the need to develop climate change mainstreaming and response strategies, but does not emphasize the need for improved information to inform the strategies.

target.comment: 1. At least updated Agenda for Transformation (to be revised in 2017) to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period.

actual.comment: The ongoing collaboration with the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning around the EWS Project implementation and other fora organized by other NAPA and National Projects as well as the UNDP will guarantee an entry point for the revision of the AfT when the time comes. The MFDP leads the process of developing the Nation's development agenda and is a member of the Project Steering Committee. The EWS is making inputs into the development of the National Adaptation Plan (NAP) for Liberia and is poised to integrate climate information into national and sectorial plans.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Indicators: -Increased levels of dialogue at the national and local level on strategies to improve transparency and accountability -No. of initiatives between oversight institutions and line ministries to improve transparency and accountability
Indicators: -Procedural and performance standards established , based on the findings of risk assessments and audits -Increased efficiency in financial management and service delivery -Increased levels of access to information to official data
Indicators •Procedural and performance standards established , based on the findings of audits -Improved capacity to manage development funds and deliver services
Indicator: -Increased access to information on concessions and revenues generated -No. of Public hearing of LEITI reports in the catchment area of concessionaries institutionalized -Extent of Civil society (including women and youth organizations) and media engagement in providing information on all aspects of the industry in an easily-accessible format to the public
Indicator: -Increased knowledge of UNCAC and the UNCAC self-assessment process -Increased coordination and networking between oversight institutions, ministries and agencies, civil society and media around UNCAC -Measures taken to address gaps identified through the self-assessment processes
Indicators: -Increased capacity of LACC -Level of investigative independence of LACC (both proactive and reactive detection -Increased public perception of LACC’s capability to address corruption
Indicators: -Existence of participatory initiatives (involving women and youth) to promote transparency and accountability at national and local level, particularly in service delivery -Increased levels of access to information -Increased coverage of media on transparency and accountability -Increased coverage of media on transparency and accountability with women and youth specific messages

baseline.comment:
Baseline: high awareness of corruption issues but limited dialogue and engagement on prevention, transparency and accountability
Baseline: -varying levels of prevention measures adopted in line ministries -limited data on efficiency in service delivery and financial management in line ministries and agencies, and on service delivery -Corruption risk in the Education sector assessed.
Baseline: •lack of internal control in county administration (based on 2010 audit report) •limited capacity to manage development funds and deliver services
Baseline: -Lack of consolidated information on concessions awarded, revenues generated and invested and environmental and social impact of extractive industry and natural resource sector - limited compliance of concessionaries to requirements of EITI reporting - limited knowledge and confidence of general public in the LEITI process
Baseline: -Limited awareness of UNCAC and opportunities presented by UNCAC to support anti-corruption reforms
Baseline: -Limited capacity of LACC to investigate and prosecute corruption cases. -Investigation rates of LACC caseload is only nine percent
Baseline: -Emerging capacity of Civil society and community based organizations to monitor service delivery -Lack of information on services provided at the local level - Limited capacity of CSOs and media to monitor service delivery

target.comment: Collaborative framework implemented Audits conducted Action Plans developed and implemented Education Bulletins constructed Integrity Clubs established internal information platforms and systems developed focal points identified Workshops to raise awareness organized Awareness workshop on UNCAC and UNCAC self-assessment conducted Technical workshop conducted on UNCAC self-assessment Capacity assessment conducted Capacity development plan developed specifically for increasing prosecutorial capacity Capacity development plan implemented and MoJ prosecutors, LACC prosecutors, investigators and lawyers trained in the handling of corruption cases, including in case selection, and forensic financial investigation service charters developed ( MOH & MOE) outreach activities conducted Civil society and community based organization take part in national and local dialogue

actual.comment: Target constrained by EVD breakout

target.comment: -UNCAC self-assessment conducted to identify gaps and action plan developed - capacity assessment of LACC and MoJ prosecutorial capacity undertaken and capacity plan developed - Integrity clubs in 5 schools in Monsterado established. -Capacity development plan developed specifically for increasing prosecutorial capacity

Baseline: (2014) Gaps identified in micro-assessment for procurement certification capacities of 40 MACs.
Baseline:(2013) MACs M&E capacity limited and 32 MACs M&E assessed. No organized means of reporting
Baseline:(2013) Draft M&E and capacity building plans developed
Baseline:(2014) NIM Toolkit produced and NIM trainings workshops held, for sustainability, NIM training needs to be institutionalized through LIPA
Output 2: Baseline: (2014) 50 percent
Baseline: (2013)1 private sector engagement meeting held
Baseline: (2011) Draft NGO policy in place
Baseline: (1998) NGO database created
Baseline: (2013/2014) 2 Trainings already conducted
Output 4: Baseline: (2014) New functional areas for hired Directors and Assistant Directors under the newly created LRA and MFDP
Baseline: (2014) No IT strategy in place; Data center under construction by UNDP; It team currently has one vehicle
Output 5: Baseline: (2014) Social-economic data is available but needs to be updated
Baseline: (2014) Economic papers are written but no regular economic journals produced
Output 6:
Baselines: 1. Limited publicity of UNDP’s contribution to development (source: ADR report) 2. Draft partnership and communication strategy in place

target.comment:
Output 1: NIM Toolkit launch 25 procurement staff 2 RBM Training 30 M&E reports 150 Manuals 1 NIM training curriculum and training modules
Output 2:
3 Private sector meetings 2 Civil society meetings NGO policy NGO Database 6 trainings (80% male, 20% women)
Output 4: 10 Directors 25 Assistant Directors LRA Data Center MFDP strategic Plan
Output 5: 1 Social –economic report 2 Economic journals

actual.comment:
Deepening of National Implementation policies and business processes skills of 74 staff from 23 SET IPs and RPs conducted and participants benefited from practical orientation on the use of the NIM Toolkit.
NIM Toolkit launched and NIM Toolkit training curriculum and training modules draft developed by the Liberia Institute of Public Administration (LIPA) for short term refresher/orientation training of national partners. LDSP used NIM Toolkit for NIM training of their implementing agencies.
LRA Data Center established and equipped for effective and efficient of tax revenue collection.
PPCC Hands-on Facility and Toll free Call center established to enhance the public procurement system by improving upon the existing capacity of public procurement practitioners, thereby allowing for increased proficiency and efficiency in the delivery of the entities’ core mandates and strategic plans, as well as in the achievement of the Government’s national development priorities as set forth in the Agenda for Transformation (AfT).
MFDP strategic plan produced and 300 printed
54 MFDP staff members comprising of Directors, Assistant Directors and Senior Analyst from benefited from a RBM Training specifically tailored to enhance skills to deliver the 3 year Strategic Plan.
62 (42 males & 20 females) Planning and Budgeting officers, and M&E officers from 20 MACs RBM knowledge and skills capacities were improved through training.
82 (26 Female and 56 Male) key Sub-national level development actors from 15 county comprising of 15 County Superintendents, Assistant Superintendents for Fiscal Affairs, Assistant Superintendents for Development, and Regional Development Officers underwent through an orientation program on fiscal and development planning.

indicator.description: Fully equip at least 720 officers and men of the BIN and LNP to fight Ebola and maintain law and order;Cover at least 1000 EVD training for security management and other officials covering 8 counties;provide social safety net support to at least 4000 EVD affected persons in the 8 counties.

baseline.comment: Limited capability of BIN and the LNP to undertake EVD related responsibilities of quarantining communities, providing escort/protection to healthcare workers and healthcare facilities, supervising burials of victims and ensuring enhanced border surveillance within the context of the Ebola response.

target.comment: fully equip 1,000 BIN and LNP operatives with state of the art communication equipment and mobility in all official border points
